summary.title: Drawings of Runic Inscriptions in Stavanger District

docTitle.titlePart:
Stavangriensia
transmiſsa
ab
Epiſcopo
Domino M. Thoma Vegnero
1639

support.p: Paper. There are three various watermarks: An ewer with a cross and a crescent carrying the capital letters P D C. This watermark appears 11 times. The second watermark only appears at fol. 10 and 27. It is also resembling an ewer, but the lid is a quatrefoil and the capital letters seem to be L O A. The third watermark appears four times and seem to resemble a baluster centrepiece with candlesticks placed on either side of the centrepiece. Some indistinct capital latters on the centrepiece can be read as F I S.

supportDesc.extent: i + 27 + i. 260-305 170-400 . Most of the leaves, however, measure 300 200

foliation.p: Foliated 1-27 in red ink in the top right-hand corner of the recto pages the title page is no 1. Modern pencil foliation 2-27 in the bottom right-hand corner of the recto-pages

condition.p: Most of the leaves are more or less torn.

layout.p: AM 368 fol comprises a draft; perhaps that explains why the text is scattered haphazardly around the illustrations. The orientation of the texts and the illustrations vary, possibly due to the way the leaves subsequently were bound. It appears as if the text and illustrations were made on single, loose leaves, as all of the content, except from a copy of a runic inscription of † Sele Cross on fol. 18v, is written on the rectos. Bishop Thomas Wegner, however, added notes on some of the versos.

handNote.p: Written and drawn by an unknown emissary of the then bishop of Stavanger, Thomas Wegner.
The title page was written by Ole Worm.

additions.p: On fol. 19v, the beginning of a hymn for Sunday, midlent, composed by the Danish poet Thomas Kingo is found: den ſom mig føder dett er att gud min herre mig fattis j alted huad min nødtørft Kingo IV339.
On the blank leaves, fols 4v, 5v, 9v, 10v, 15v, 16v, 25v, 26v, Bishop Thomas Wegner wrote the names of the deaneries in which the runic objects were found.

binding.p: The boards were originally covered in written parchment from a Missale Scardense; this has now been transferred to Access. 7a α, Hs 1.
Now the booklet is bound in a cardboard binding with a marbled paper cover with spines and corners of cloth. On the pastedown it says: AM. 368. fol — Overført: 27 bl. 17/5 86..

origin.p: The illlustrated pamphlets of notes, AM 366-371 fol. forms part of a larger corpus commonly referred to as Præsteindberetninger til Ole Worm (‘Priests’ Reports submitted to Ole Worm’). In the seventeenth century the doctor, scholar of antiquities and polymath Worm collected curiosities for his private collection of antiquities, Museum Wormianum, while simultaneously pursuing an interest in prehistoric Denmark, and in particular runic inscriptions. To this end, on the 11th of August 1622, Worm sent a missive to every bishop in Denmark requesting that they instruct their rectors to investigate ancient monuments found in their parishes, and primarily objects featuring runic inscriptions. Worm then used these handwritten reports as the basis of his printed book, Monumenta Danica from 1643, a work which laid the foundations of runic research in Denmark.

What links AM 366-371 fol. together is that they contain some of the earliest written accounts of runic inscriptions and petroglyphs in the former Danish kingdom, which at that time encompassed Skåne, Halland and Blekinge in present-day Sweden, Norway, including Bohuslän (which at that time was part of Norway) as well as Iceland and the Faroe Islands.

listBibl.bibl: Hafstein, Bodies of Knowledge. Ole Worm & Collecting in Late Renaissance Scandinavia
